review.title: Mining Local Gazetteers of Literary Chinese with CRF and Pattern based Methods for Biographical Information in Chinese History
review.abstract: Person names and location names are essential building blocks for identifying events and social networks in historical documents that were written in literary Chinese. We take the lead to explore the research on algorithmically recognizing named entities in literary Chinese for historical studies with language-model based and conditional-random-field based methods, and extend our work to mining the document structures in historical documents. Practical evaluations were conducted with texts that were extracted from more than 220 volumes of local gazetteers (Difangzhi). Difangzhi is a huge and the single most important collection that contains information about officers who served in local government in Chinese history. Our methods performed very well on these realistic tests. Thousands of names and addresses were identified from the texts. A good portion of the extracted names match the biographical information currently recorded in the China Biographical Database (CBDB) of Harvard University, and many others can be verified by historians and will become as new additions to CBDB.

sections.heading: B. Problem Definitions
sections.text: We want to build a system that can extract biographical information from the DFZ in order to enrich the content of the CBDB. Current content of the CBDB has been extracted from sources other than the DFZ. [19] Therefore, we are interested in finding all kinds of biographical information in the DFZ. In this paper, we focus on questions of searching for personal names and place names and cover some relevant topics, such as verifying whether the places were places of birth and finding paragraph boundaries. In the long term, we will also expand to social networks and personal careers.

sections.heading: B. Evaluation: Labeled Data
sections.text: We evaluated the effectiveness of using linear CRF models to recognize person and place names in the DFZ with the data described in Section II.D. Given the original labels, we were able to create characteristics for all characters and then perform 5-fold cross-validations. We classified the characters into seven categories: NB, NI, NE, AB, AI, AE, and O. We used N and A to identify name and place. B, I, and E each denote beginning, internal, and end. O means other. Thus, for example, NB is for the first character of a person's name, and AE is the last character of a place's name. We conducted several experiments for CRF models that looked at different combinations of features we discussed in Section IVA. Classification results were measured using standard metrics, i.e. precision, callback, and F1 measurement, which are very common for information retrieval.4 Here are the experimental results for five combinations.
